title: Is it Ok for the compiler to crash if proc_macro contains unsound code? Documentation is unclear.

labels.name: A-docs
labels.description: Area: documentation for any part of the project, including the compiler, standard library, and tools

body:
I'm not really sure whether that's a documentation issue or really a compiler bug.

When we were discussing bug [in the indoc](https://github.com/dtolnay/indoc/issues/51) crate [H2CO3](https://users.rust-lang.org/u/H2CO3) made shocking (to me) [assertion](https://users.rust-lang.org/t/new-library-for-lifetime-erased-borrowing-across-threads/85910/20): *even if there **is** a soundness issue in a crate, this should not cause the compiler to crash*.
 
Note that crate in question is a proc_macro crate which, apparently, can create broken `String` (which doesn't contain valid UTF-8) and thus I, naïvely, assumed that if it breaks [The Soundness Pledge](https://raphlinus.github.io/rust/2020/01/18/soundness-pledge.html) then compiler may only burn and crash in flames… but I have just checked and, indeed, [reference](https://doc.rust-lang.org/reference/procedural-macros.html) doesn't even mention soundness.

While the issue with `indoc` is a minor one to me, the question of whether compiler should/could expect that procmacro contains valid code is a bit different one.

P.S. Also it sounds as if issue with `indoc` itself is problem with a compiler, too (`indoc` is tiny crate with no `unsafe` code thus it, probably, should be able to be unsound), but that's separate.
